But when Varus's sexuality was core to their story, the boards flipped their shit

That's because of a lot of things. For one Varus actually had a pretty interesting backstory to begin with, being someone who chose duty over emotion, only to regret it then choose vengeance over all (or something like that), but the big thing, at least for me, was that Varus was a father. Now say what you will about heteronormativity or whatever it's called (that is the belief that a character is assumed to be straight unless otherwise stated) but the fact is for most champs in league sexuality isn't really talked about like at all, and even less talk of any sort of ongoing relationships or family. So when you take one of the only champs to be specifically stated to be a father and make him gay well... like sure I know plenty were just mad he was gay but honestly a lot of people just didn't like how it largely ignored old lore to push what felt like an agenda. Like I woulda been fine with it otherwise but like literally he was the only champ in league to have had a son. Also nobody likes hard retcons.

I'm just saying look at the op here even.  The op is saying it's cool to see some LGBT representation and they're barely breaking even between the positive and negative votes.  It's easy to see why LGBT people need representation when the very acknowledgement that they exist is met with negativity

They flipped because, for all intents and purposes, it seemed like they just tossed out his original background story for the sake of, "Well, we don't have any gay characters, so let's completely rewrite Varus' backstory so we can have one."  He had a backstory that people liked and that was unique in League, and it was completely thrown away when no one asked for it to be, which makes it seem like Riot is just trying to be "progressive" by just throwing some sexually non-binary characters without regard for how that affects their personality and doing so while stepping on the toes of long-time players who related to Varus' original story.

They saw an opportunity to fit Varus's into the Darkin lore, which he didn't before.  It involved totally rewriting his story to make it more entertwined with existing lore and it presented a good opportunity for him to be made of a same sex couple since it explains how he's fully masculine despite being made of 2 lovers.

What does “tossing homosexuality into the mix just for the sake of it” even mean? Does there have to be a “reason” for a character to be gay? For instance, if Senna was a man would you consider Lycuab to be a forced gay character?

Well putting it in terms of Chekhov's Gun: What's the point of mentioning that they're lesbian/straight/jet engine/whatever if it's never going to be relevant down the line?

This particular instance is far more forgivable given it was told to us over a tweet, but if we were writing a story let's suppose, you don't need to point out a character's sexuality if it doesn't do anything with the plot or that character's, well, character. Overemphasizing those details about your character is the work of fanfic writers and DA OC makers.

EDIT: Here let's use your "Lycuab" example

If Senna straight up didn't exist but Lucian is still pissed off at Thresh/demons for whatever reason, there would be no point in mentioning Lycuab's sexuality at all.

If Senna was a dude, it becomes important to mention that Lucian is gay to establish that romantic relationship and thus the gravity of Lucian's loss of his partner.

As far as I am concerned, the sexuality of any League character shouldn't really matter unless it matters.  Having a character "identify" as a given sexuality should only matter if their sexuality is inherent to their character, like Miss Fortune, Evelynn, or even Taric.  Telling us "champion is lesbian" does nothing except make the champion divisive between conservative and progressive players when that champ's sexuality won't even be expressed in the game.  Like, if you WANT her character interactions to HINT at it, fine.  Dumbledore was never stated as being gay in Harry Potter because his sexuality had no effect or bearing on the story, but people could infer that maybe he was by small hints in his actions and personality, allowing people to interpret him how they want.  And really, that's the best thing you can do for a character; write them in such a way that they can be interpreted differently by different people, allowing them to have some intrigue and holding interest to a wider audience because people will read into their behaviors differently based on their own tastes.  And when a character has multiple interpretations, it makes them even more colorful and gives them a broader, more nuanced personality.  Given that "color" was supposed to be the main theme of the new champ, I think just having a creator just blithely label her as "lesbian" is more of a disservice to both the character and her future players than a service.

I think that's the point, though. Sexuality shouldn't be divisive.

If the response really WAS 'who cares?', then there'd be no backlash for it as a trivia point. Imagine that there was a stigma against certain family lineages in the US (Interesting trivia: This is a real thing in Japan). Certain areas in the country are populated with these people as a result of them being social pariahs, resulting in certain areas becoming sort've unseemly, or weird.

League makes no real effort to throw out stereotypical version of these people, but - whether for reasons of inclusive diversity, or just because it fits the idea in their head - decides to note in a trivia point that a certain character is from a certain part of Runeterra that is obviously based on those unseemly parts of society.

Just a footnote.

Would backlash to this be any less justified to backlash to a person's sexual preference?

I used to have the mindset of 'why make them gay if there's no REASON for it?!', but upon reflection realized that was kind of dumb. Why make a person blonde for no reason? Or make them enjoy using yoyos? Why have them secretly have hopes and dreams that are never expanded upon?

Sometimes things just are. And sometimes things are, because they're purposely made to be.
But even if someone's purposely made gay.... so what? Why is 'lesbianism' considered a disservice? Would it help if she were given a girlfriend to interact with on the regular?

I think that'd make the people 'offended' by this stuff even angrier. =P
